Fig. 5 Fig. 6 The long-term durability test results for the simultaneous CO and C3H6 oxidation showing (a) CO conversion and (b) C3H6 conversion. The oxidation were performed at 240 °C using an inlet gas flow of 0.4% CO, 0.1% C3H6, 10% O2, and balance He at 120,000 ml g−1 h−1. The CO conversions for all the catalysts were 100% except the CCC-a. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 In-situ DRIFT spectra of (a) CCC and (b) CCCM catalysts for simultaneous CO and C3H6 oxidation while increasing temperatures by 50 °C. The catalysts were exposed to the reactant gases consisting of 0.8% CO, 0.2% C3H6, 10% O2, and balance Ar for 10 min, then IR spectra were collected at each temperature. The numbers denoted in black and blue indicate the peak positions induced from CO and C3H6, respectively (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article). Mn-doped CuOCo3O4 CeO2 catalyst with enhanced activity and durability for hydrocarbon oxidation Junemin Bae Beom-Sik Kim Hojin Jeong Hyunjoo Lee ⁎ Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Daejeon 34141, South Korea Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology Daejeon 34141 South Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A ternary oxide catalyst composed of CuOCo3O4 CeO2 (CCC) has great potential for automotive exhaust treatment due to its excellent CO oxidation activity and high resistance against hydrocarbon inhibition. However, current CCC catalyst exhibits significantly lower hydrocarbon oxidation activity comparing to CO oxidation, and deactivation occurs severely after hydrothermal aging. Here, we show that a Mn-doped CCC (CCCM) catalyst exhibits enhanced activity and durability for C3H6 oxidation, while maintaining the high activity for CO oxidation. The Mn-doping prevented sintering and phase separation of the Co3O4 phase even after hydrothermal aging at 750 °C for 25 h. The Mn was selectively doped into Co3O4 by substituting Co3+ octahedral sites in the Co3O4 spinel structure. The presence of Mn with a larger cation radius induced lattice expansion of the Co3O4 phase with more surface active oxygen. This strategy can provide a facile way to develop better non-PGM catalysts for emission control. Keywords CuOCo3O4 CeO2 Diesel oxidation catalyst Propene Surface oxygen Durability 1 Introduction As environmental regulations for the pollutants from automobiles have been strengthened, efforts have been continued to reduce fuel consumption and exhaust emissions [1]. New combustion techniques, such as reactivity-controlled compression ignition (RCCI), can improve the fuel economy and reduce the emission of NOx and particulate matter [2]. But the resulting lower temperatures at the exhaust would make the after-treatment catalysts produce more CO and hydrocarbons [3,4]. Better catalysts, which can operate at lower temperature, is highly desired. Platinum-group metals (PGMs) have been widely used as diesel oxidation catalysts (DOCs) because they show excellent low temperature activity for CO oxidation [5–7]. However, the high activity for CO oxidation is degraded significantly in the presence of hydrocarbon due to competitive adsorption of CO and hydrocarbon on the metal surface [8,9]. Additionally, the after-treatment section often experiences high temperature up to 750 °C causing the severe sintering of metal nanoparticles [10–12]. Non-PGM catalysts have received much attention because of much lower price and relatively good activity for CO oxidation at low temperatures [13–15]. The composite oxides of CuOCo3O4 CeO2, which is denoted as CCC below, showed high activity for CO oxidation without degradation even in the presence of C3H6 because the active sites for CO oxidation and C3H6 oxidation are different [16–18]. While the active site for CO oxidation is the interface between CuO and Co3O4 or CeO2, the active site for C3H6 oxidation is Co3O4. However, the activity of CCC catalyst for C3H6 oxidation is poor at low temperatures and the CCC catalyst suffers from severe sintering after hydrothermal treatment [18,19]. Co3O4 phase is known to have high activity for the oxidation of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) [20,21]. Its activity could be promoted by introducing other transition metal dopants, which produced more surface active oxygen species [22–24]. Especially, Mn has been reported to enhance the activity of Co3O4 for the oxidation of various VOCs with strong interaction between Mn and Co [25–30]. In this work, we synthesized Mn-doped CCC catalyst, which is denoted as CCCM below, by a simple co-precipitation method. Mn was selectively doped into Co3O4 phase enhancing the activity for C3H6 oxidation and the durability after hydrothermal treatment. The structure of CCCM and the role of Mn in simultaneous CO and C3H6 oxidation were investigated in detail. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis The CuOCo3O4 CeO2 (CCC) catalyst was synthesized by co-precipitation [18]. Copper nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, Aldrich), cobalt chloride hexahydrate (CoCl2·6H2O, Aldrich), and cerium nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)2·6H2O, Aldrich) were simultaneously dissolved in 25 ml of deionized water at a molar ratio of Cu:Co:Ce = 1:5:5. Then, 25 ml of NaOH solution (0.375 M) was added to the solution dropwise under vigorous stirring. After 1 h, the precipitate was washed with deionized water and ethanol, and dried at 50 °C in a vacuum oven overnight. The obtained cake was crushed in a ceramic mortar to fine powder, and calcined at 600 °C for 4 h in air. The Mn-doped CuOCo3O4 CeO2 (CCCM) catalyst was synthesized using the same method except that manganese nitrate hydrate (Mn(NO3)2·xH2O, Aldrich) was also added with a molar ratio of Cu:Co:Ce:Mn = 1:5:5:1. The single metal oxides of Co3O4, CeO2, and MnO2 were also synthesized for characterizations. The CCC and CCCM catalysts were hydrothermally aged at 750 °C for 25 h while flowing 144.5 ml min−1 of air with 10% H2O [31,32]. The aged CCC and CCCM catalysts were denoted by CCC-a and CCCM-a, respectively. 2.2 Catalytic oxidation reactions Simultaneous CO and C3H6 oxidation were performed using a quartz fixed-bed reactor with 50 mg of the catalyst at atmospheric pressure. The catalyst was pre-treated at 100 °C under He flow for 1 h, then the sample was cooled to room temperature. The reaction was performed with a gas stream consisting of 0.4% CO, 0.1% C3H6, 10% O2, and balance He. The total flow rate was 100 ml min−1 (space velocity (SV) = 120,000 ml g−1 h−1). The sample was held at each temperature to reach a steady-state in a continuous feed stream. The product gases were monitored using an on-line gas chromatograph (GC, Younglin GC 6500) equipped with packed bed carboxen 1000 column (75035, SUPELCO, 15 ft × 1/8 in. × 2.1 mm)/capillary column (GS-GASPRO, Agilent Technologies, 30 m × 0.32 mm) and thermal conductivity detector (TCD)/flame ionization detector (FID). NO oxidation was also performed with a gas stream consisting of 0.4% CO, 0.1% C3H6, 0.05% NO, 10% O2, and balance Ar. The product gas including NOx was monitored using a FT-IR spectrometer (Nicolet iS10, Thermo Scientific) with a gas cell (internal volume 0.2 L). 2.3 Characterizations Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained using a Tecnai G2 F30 S-Twin (FEI) with an voltage of 300 kV. The energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping and high angle annular dark field-scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) images were obtained using a Talos F200X (FEI) with an voltage of 200 kV. The actual metal contents of the catalysts were measured by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES 720, Agilent). The BET surface area was measured by N2 adsorption at −196 °C using a Tristar II 3020 (Micromeritics). The crystalline structure was observed by X-ray diffraction (XRD; Rigaku, Cu Kα radiation). Raman spectra were recorded at room temperature using a LabRAM HR evolution visible NIR (HORIBA) equipped with a charge-coupled device (CCD) detector and a 514 nm argon ion laser as an excitation source. The surface chemical state was investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; K-alpha, ThermoVG Scientific), and the binding energy was estimated using the maximum intensity of C 1 s signal at 284.8 eV as a reference. Extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) measurements were conducted at the 8C XAFS beamline of the Pohang Light Source (PLS). H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and O2 temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD) were performed on a BELCAT-B (BEL) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). For H2-TPR, 50 mg of the catalyst was pre-treated under Ar at 100 °C for 1 h, and cooled down to room temperature. Then, the sample was exposed to 5% H2 balanced with Ar with a flow rate of 50 ml min−1, and heated to 1000 °C. For O2-TPD, 50 mg of the catalyst was pre-treated under He stream at 300 °C for 1 h, and cooled down to room temperature. The 5% O2 balanced with He flow was subsequently introduced at room temperature for 1 h, and purged with He for 30 min. Then, the catalyst was heated to 1000 °C under He with a flow rate of 50 ml min−1. The CO and C3H6 oxidation were monitored by in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier-transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) using a Nicolet iS-50 (Thermo Scientific). The catalyst 4 mg was ground with 196 mg of KBr, and the mixed powder was placed into a DRIFTS cell. The cell was purged with Ar at 100 °C for 1 h, and cooled down to room temperature. To monitor the formation of intermediate species during the reaction, CO and C3H6 oxidation was performed with an inlet gas flow consisting of 0.8% CO, 0.2% C3H6, 10% O2, and balance Ar while increasing the cell temperature. IR spectra were collected after exposing to the reactant gas for 10 min at each temperature. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Properties of CCCM catalyst HAADF-STEM and EDS elemental mappings images were obtained to determine the morphology and elemental distribution of the catalysts. Elemental distribution in Fig. S1 shows that all Cu, Co, and Ce were uniformly distributed in the as-prepared CCC catalyst, but the Co domain showed phase separation after hydrothermal aging, which was performed by flowing air with 10% H2O for 25 h at 750 °C. Mn-doped CCC catalyst was prepared by adding Mn precursor as well during the synthesis of CCC catalyst. The actual metal contents of the catalysts were shown in Table S1. Elemental distribution in Fig. S2 shows that all Cu, Co, Ce, and Mn were uniformly distributed in the as-prepared CCCM catalyst, and the catalyst also showed the uniform distribution even after the hydrothermal aging. Whereas Cu and Ce showed no change after the aging for both CCC and CCCM catalysts, Co phase showed distinct change; Co phase separation was clearly observed in CCC catalyst but the phase separation was much less in CCCM catalyst as shown in Fig. 1 . The textural properties and crystalline structures of the catalysts were observed. The XRD data of the CCC catalyst in Fig. 2 show that Co3O4 spinel structure and CeO2 face-centered cubic fluorite structure were observed without any CuO or other impurities [33,34]. Cu was finely distributed on the CeO2 and Co3O4 phases. The CCCM catalyst showed nearly the same XRD pattern, but slight shift was observed in only Co3O4 peaks to lower diffraction angles, indicating the expansion of Co3O4 lattice cell. The CeO2 peak showed no shift. This difference became more evident after the hydrothermal aging. The Co3O4 lattice expansion suggests that Mn cations (Mn3+, r = 0.79 Å) favorably substitute smaller Co cations (Co3+, r = 0.75 Å), not replacing larger Ce cations (Ce4+, r = 1.01 Å). The crystallite sizes and lattice parameters of the Co3O4 and CeO2 phase in the catalysts were estimated as shown in Table 1 . The Co3O4 phase was sintered less in the presence of Mn after the hydrothermal aging. The hydrothermal aging also leaded to appearance of CuO phase in CCC, but the CuO phase was smaller in CCCM. The formation of Mn-Co solid solution can inhibit the growth of Co3O4 nanoparticles [28,35]. Fig. 3 (a) shows Co K-edge Fourier-transformed (FT) EXAFS spectra of the catalysts. The first peak at ˜1.5 Å corresponds to interatomic distance of octahedral CoO [36,37], while the peaks at ˜2.5 Å and ˜3.0 Å correspond to interatomic distances from octahedral Co atom to neighboring Co atom at the octahedral or tetrahedral site, respectively [38,39]. The magnitude of octahedral Co coordination peaks in the CCCM catalysts was much weaker than that of the CCC catalysts, indicating that Mn-doping made Co octahedral peaks lower [37]. Mn K-edge FT-EXAFS spectra in Fig. 3(b) show that the CCCM catalysts had much larger octahedral MnO peak at ˜1.5 Å than pure MnO2 [40]. A new peak was observed at ˜2.1 Å while the peak for octahedral MnMn at ˜2.5 Å did not appear at the CCCM catalysts. The new peak seems to result from octahedral MnCo interaction with localized distortion [41,42]. EXAFS results suggest that the doped Mn occupies the octahedral Co sites in Co3O4 spinel structure. Raman spectroscopy was further performed to confirm the structural features of the catalysts in Fig. S3. The peaks at 190, 510, 605, and 675 cm−1 are attributed to F2g 1, F2g 2, F2g 3, and A1g vibration modes of Co3O4 spinel structure, respectively [43,44]. The peak at 460 cm−1 is assigned to the overlap of F2g mode of CeO2 fluorite structure and Eg mode of Co3O4 spinel structure [45]. The high-frequency band at 675 cm−1, which corresponds to the vibration mode of octahedral Co3+ [22,23], significantly decreased after Mn-doping, suggesting that Mn cations substitute Co3+ at the octahedral sites [22]. No distinct MnO2 bands were observed, indicating uniform distribution of Mn. The surface chemical states of the catalysts were examined by XPS in Fig. 4 , and corresponding quantitative results were listed in Table 2 . Whereas Cu and Ce peaks were not shifted after Mn-doping, Co peak was shifted from 779.1 eV for Co 2p3/2 in the as-prepared CCC catalyst to 779.6 eV in the as-prepared CCCM catalyst. The same trend was observed after the hydrothermal aging as well. This shift indicates that the ratio of Co3+/Co2+decreased in the CCCM catalyst [29,46]. In the spinel structure of Co3O4, Co2+ and Co3+ ions are located in tetrahedral and octahedral sites, respectively [47]. The decrease in Co3+ concentration suggests that Co3+ in the octahedral sites is replaced by Mn [29]. The Mn peak in Fig. 4(c) shows that Mn peak was shifted from 642.2 eV in MnO2 to 641.7 eV in the CCCM catalyst, indicating that the surface Mn was partially reduced and the ratio of Mn3+/Mn4+ increased in the CCCM catalyst [46]. This is consistent with the claim that Co3+ in the octahedral sites is replaced by Mn. The Cu peak was slightly shifted after the hydrothermal aging regardless of Mn-doping as shown in Fig. S4, indicating the sintering of Cu2O species. The O 1s peaks were deconvoluted into Oα and Oβ as shown in Fig. 4(d). The Oα peak around 529–530 eV was assigned to defective oxygen or oxygen chemisorbed on the surface, and the Oβ peak around 531–532 eV was assigned to lattice oxygen [25,29]. The peak area ratio of Oα/Oβ increased from 0.48 to 0.67 after Mn-doping, indicating that defective or chemisorbed oxygen species were formed more in the CCCM catalyst. After the hydrothermal aging, the difference became more evident; the ratio increased from 0.34 in CCC-a to 0.72 in CCCM-a. The defective oxygen can be generated to maintain an electrostatic balance between Mn and Co cations from unbalanced charges and lattice distortion [48,49]. The redox properties of the catalysts were investigated using H2-TPR in Fig. S5(a), and corresponding quantitative data were listed in Table S2. For the CCC catalyst, the peak at 171 °C is attributed to the reduction of CuO interacting with Co3O4 and CeO2, and the large peaks at 187 and 278 °C are attributed to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and subsequent reduction of CoO to metallic Co, respectively [16,17]. The Co reduction peaks were shifted to higher temperatures after Mn-doping, indicating that the interaction of Co with the support became stronger. The same trend was observed after the hydrothermal aging. Similar behaviors have been reported on the Fe-doped Co3O4 catalysts, suggesting that doped metals induce structural defects forming anionic vacancies [29,50,51]. The surface oxygen properties of the catalysts were investigated using O2-TPD in Fig. S5(b), and corresponding quantitative data were listed in Table S3. The desorption peak below 300 °C is attributed to the surface active oxygen such as chemisorbed O2 − and O− species [30,52], while the desorption peaks at 300–650 °C and above 650 °C correspond to surface lattice oxygen and bulk lattice oxygen, respectively [53,54]. A slight shift of the first peak to a higher temperature after Mn-doping might indicate that surface oxygen species was changed from O2 − to O− [46,53,55]. Clearly, the CCCM catalysts possessed more surface active oxygen species. 3.2 Simultaneous CO and C3H6 oxidation The catalytic activities of the as-prepared and aged catalysts were evaluated for simultaneous CO and C3H6 oxidation as shown in Fig. 5 . The CCC and CCCM catalysts showed the same high activity by achieving 100% CO conversion at 155 °C. The CO oxidation on the CCC catalyst has been reported to occur mainly by extracting oxygen from weakened metal-oxygen bonds at the interfacial sites between CuO and Co3O4 or CeO2 [17,18,56]. The Mn-doping did not change the active sites for CO oxidation. Fig. S6 shows the activity for CO oxidation in the absence or presence of C3H6. The CCCM catalyst showed high resistance to C3H6 inhibitory effect on CO oxidation like the CCC catalyst. After the hydrothermal aging, the temperature at which 100% CO conversion was achieved increased significantly to 235 °C for the CCC-a catalyst, while the temperature increased only to 185 °C for the CCCM-a catalyst. It has been reported that the CCC catalyst showed low temperature light-off due to highly dispersed Cu sites interacting with CeO2, while high CO conversion could be maintained due to Co3O4 phase [18]. The Co3O4 crystallites in the CCCM-a catalyst were aggregated less after the hydrothermal aging, preserving the interfacial sites more. This leaded to lower T100 CO, which is the temperature with 100% CO conversion, for the CCCM-a catalyst. Fig. S7 shows NO oxidation results on the catalysts. The CCC and CCCM catalyst showed the nearly same NO conversion, while the CCCM-a showed better activity than the CCC-a catalyst. C3H6 oxidation is known to occur at the Co3O4 phase in the CCC catalyst [18]. As shown in Fig. 5(b), the as-prepared CCCM catalyst showed better activity with T100 C3H6 of 285 °C than the as-prepared CCC catalyst with T100 C3H6 of 325 °C. After the hydrothermal aging, the CCC-a catalyst exhibited much higher T100 C3H6 of 425 °C, whereas T100 C3H6 of the CCCM-a catalyst was 355 °C. Complete oxidation of C3H6 on the metal oxides requires an initial C–H bond cleavage, which occurs through a reaction with electrophilic oxygen generated by O2 adsorption on the surface [18,20,57]. We previously reported that surface lattice oxygen on metal oxides typically plays a lesser role in C3H6 oxidation [58]. As shown in the XPS O 1s and O2-TPD results, the CCCM catalysts have more surface active oxygen, such as chemisorbed O2 − and O− species. The more surface active oxygen in the CCCM catalysts resulted in higher activity for C3H6 oxidation. The effect of Mn amount in the CCCM catalyst was investigated in Fig. S8. When the ratio of Cu:Co:Ce:Mn = 1:5:5:X was changed as X = 0, 0.5, 1, 1.5, and 2, the CCCM catalyst with X = 1 showed the best CO and C3H6 oxidation activity. Arrhenius plots and the apparent activation energies were obtained for the CO and C3H6 oxidations. The activation energy for the aged catalysts decreased after Mn-doping from 42.8 kJ mol−1 to 36.7 kJ mol−1 for CO oxidation and from 49.6 kJ mol−1 to 41.6 kJ mol−1 for C3H6 oxidation. The long-term durability of the as-prepared and aged catalysts was tested by running the simultaneous CO and C3H6 oxidation at 240 °C, and the conversions are shown in Fig. 6 . When the conversion was compared after 80 h of the reaction for the aged catalysts, the CO conversion increased from 86.3% to 100% and the C3H6 conversion increased from 17.1% to 50.9% after Mn-doping. The CCCM catalyst showed the enhanced activity and durability even after the long-term reaction. In-situ DRIFT analyses were performed for simultaneous CO and C3H6 oxidation at elevated temperatures to investigate the surface species formed during the reaction. Fig. 7 shows the DRIFT spectra of the as-prepared catalysts. The bands marked with black numbers at low temperatures are assigned to carbonate species originating from CO oxidation, which are bicarbonate (1465 and 1114 cm−1), bidentate carbonate (1608 and 1260 cm−1), and unidentate carbonate (1396 cm−1) [17,24,59]. The bands originating from C3H6 oxidation started to appear at higher temperatures, which are formate (1453, 1412, and 1370 cm−1), acetate (1582 and 1490 cm−1), and acetone (1678 cm−1) [24,60,61]. These species were proposed as intermediates of C3H6 oxidation on cobalt oxide surface. When the DRIFT spectra of the CCC and CCCM catalysts were compared, the trend was nearly identical indicating that the catalysts followed the same surface reaction mechanism. The aged catalysts presented the same behavior as shown in Fig. S9, except that the intensity was much weaker, probably due to much less surface area. 4 Conclusions Mn was doped into the CuOCo3O4 CeO2 (CCC) catalyst, and it was found that Mn was selectively doped into Co3O4 phase. EDS mappings images showed that the Mn-doping prevented phase separation of Co3O4 after hydrothermal aging. XRD patterns showed that only Co3O4 lattice expanded upon Mn-doping. EXAFS, raman spectroscopy, and XPS results suggested that Mn substitutes Co3+ octahedral sites in the Co3O4 spinel structure. Particularly, XPS O 1s and O2-TPD results showed that the Mn-doped catalyst possessed more surface active oxygen. The catalytic activity of the as-prepared and aged catalysts was evaluated for simultaneous CO and C3H6 oxidation. The Mn-doped catalyst presented enhanced activity and durability compared to the CCC catalyst. Remarkably, C3H6 oxidation was enhanced after Mn-doping and the extent of improvement was even larger after the hydrothermal aging. This is due to better preserved Co3O4 phase. This simple modification can be an important advance in non-PGM-based catalysts for emission control. coredata.dc:description: A ternary oxide catalyst composed of CuOCo3O4 CeO2 (CCC) has great potential for automotive exhaust treatment due to its excellent CO oxidation activity and high resistance against hydrocarbon inhibition. However, current CCC catalyst exhibits significantly lower hydrocarbon oxidation activity comparing to CO oxidation, and deactivation occurs severely after hydrothermal aging. Here, we show that a Mn-doped CCC (CCCM) catalyst exhibits enhanced activity and durability for C3H6 oxidation, while maintaining the high activity for CO oxidation. The Mn-doping prevented sintering and phase separation of the Co3O4 phase even after hydrothermal aging at 750 °C for 25 h. The Mn was selectively doped into Co3O4 by substituting Co3+ octahedral sites in the Co3O4 spinel structure. The presence of Mn with a larger cation radius induced lattice expansion of the Co3O4 phase with more surface active oxygen. This strategy can provide a facile way to develop better non-PGM catalysts for emission control.
coredata.dc:title: Mn-doped CuOCo3O4 CeO2 catalyst with enhanced activity and durability for hydrocarbon oxidation
